video.title: Internet History, Technology, and Security - Full Course from Dr. Chuck
video.description:
Learn about the history of the Internet. In this course you will learn how the Internet was created, who created it, and how it works. Along the way you will meet many of the innovators who developed the Internet and Web technologies that we use today.

🔗 Course website: https://ihts.pr4e.com/

✏️ Dr. Charles Severance developed this course. He is a Clinical Professor at the University of Michigan School of Information, where he teaches various technology-oriented courses including programming, database design, and Web development. 

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:09:28) High Stakes Research in Computing and Communication
⌨️ (0:16:50) IEEE Computer: Alan Turing at Bletchley Park
⌨️ (0:41:39) The "First" Electronic Computers Around the World
⌨️ (0:44:30) Monash Museum of Computing History Interviews
⌨️ (0:51:33) Post-War Computing and Communication
⌨️ (1:03:28) Early Academic Networking Research
⌨️ (1:19:04) Len Kleinrock: The First Two Packets on the Internet
⌨️ (1:32:06) Packet Switched Networks
⌨️ (1:37:47) Computing Conversations: Len Kleinrock on the Theory of Packets
⌨️ (1:48:30) Packet Switching and the ARPANET
⌨️ (1:49:50) Katie Hafner on the history of the ARPANET project
⌨️ (2:01:54) Supercomputers as Technology Drivers
⌨️ (2:05:38) Networked Computing, lecture by Larry Smarr on Scientific Computing
⌨️ (2:16:36) From Super Computers to NSFNet
⌨️ (2:19:57) Doug Van Houweling: Building the NSFNet
⌨️ (2:32:13) Expanding NSFNet Around the World
⌨️ (2:34:42) Nii Quaynor: Bringing the Internet to Africa
⌨️ (2:47:28) The World-Wide-Web Emerges at CERN
⌨️ Collider by the cernettes: https://youtu.be/1e1eLe1ihT0
⌨️ (2:51:28) Building the Web Around the World
⌨️ (3:26:38) Steve Job's Second-Order Effects (High resolution)
⌨️ (3:39:01) Mosaic at NCSA - The Browser for Everybody
⌨️ (3:43:01) Joseph Hardin: NCSA Mosaic
⌨️ (3:57:12) Reflecting on Mosaic
⌨️ (4:01:22) Computing Conversations with Brendan Eich
⌨️ (4:13:38) Computing Conversations: Mitchell Baker on the Mozilla Foundation
⌨️ (4:32:29) The Web, the World, and the Economy
⌨️ (4:51:05) Computing Conversations: Brian Behlendorf on the Apache Software Foundation
⌨️ (4:55:39) Open Source Wrap Up
⌨️ (4:56:06) Introduction: Link Layer
⌨️ (5:22:11) Computing Conversations: Bob Metcalfe on the First Ethernet LAN
⌨️ (5:39:03) The InterNetwork Protocol (IP)
⌨️ (6:14:35) Computing Conversations: Vint Cerf on the History of Packets
⌨️ (6:30:33) DNS - The Domain Name System
⌨️ (6:38:16) Transport Layer
⌨️ (6:47:45) Van Jacobson: The Slow-Start Algorithm
⌨️ (6:59:32) TCP Wrap Up
⌨️ (7:01:38) Application Layer
⌨️ (7:26:59) Security Introduction
⌨️ (7:29:22) Bruce Schneier: The Security Mindset
⌨️ (7:36:54) Understanding Security
⌨️ (7:46:08) Encryption and Confidentiality
⌨️ (8:06:56) Cryptographic Hashes and Integrity
⌨️ (8:15:47) Bruce Schneier: Building Cryptographic Systems
⌨️ (8:27:06) Hashing and Digital Signatures
⌨️ (8:48:54) Security Public/Private Key - Secure Sockets
⌨️ (9:08:23) Security - Integrity and Certificate Authorities

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: JD Breaux
topLevelComment.text:
Dr Chuck, I did watch your video and changed my dislike to like, but that is not why I posted here just a moment ago. For YT videos I provided in my comment a couple of important YT videos for the curious. The acceleration, the firestorm that jump started the 1940's technology leading directly to today's Internet. That credit belongs to the damned empty Coke machine at Carnegie Mellon, PA and Beserkley in CA. Mad scientists that I would love to have known.

Thank you for your efforts and time in to educating so many hungry minds (and even the time to produce your videos.) My hat off to you sir. It would be my pleasure to have know you so we could have exchanged stories. But you are where you need to be, learning all us ingent peoples.

Out of ignorance I posted this comment having seen only a couple of you videos. I'm sorry if you covered this and I missed it.

topLevelComment.author: JD Breaux
topLevelComment.text:
I was on the Internet in the 80's. I think I am better versed. I always look to see what these videos can teach me, but they always fall short BY YEARS! Another disappointment. I want to learn as I did then, but this wasted my time. Not hear to show off. The most popular card reader/punch in the IBM world was a 1401. Reader here reading card stock #5081: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J0hDuCa_KlY
It was so fast we were not allowed to wear ties in the operating room because if your tie were caught in the reader, IBM would have to be called after they cut your tie and pulled you corpse away from the machine. The 5081 was reading 80 column cards, the 5096 was for 96 column cards. 

The 5081 card, the most popular running in the late 1960's and 70's IBM 360 mainframe batch processors (even models in the 1950's). The older IBM 360's running OS would later go onto become IBM S370's. It was a beautiful era to grow up in. I dropped out of college because the pace of growth could not be documented and taught fast enough. I went on into mainframe operations in 1975 u=in an IBM S370 DOS/VS world. My roommate a programmer in the IBM S360's world coding applications. I went on to coding and an OS systems programmer and in that migration I wrote code to eliminate the card reader for batch processing. All while we were upgrading to IBM S370 MVSJES2 (Multiple Virtual Storage Job Entry Subsystem v2...the I/O spooler).
 
I had written code to convert DOS JECL to JES2 JCEL. Oh what fun that was with the very limited technology we had in those days. I had to think outside of the circle every moment of my professional carrier. All of this predated today's aging z/OS and z/VSE.

If you are in college now studying Computer Sciences, you are already too late for your diploma to really do any good unless you have your foot in the door. Get a part time job as a mainframe computer operator ASAP!!! ...or your degree will not pay off from what your degree is in and where you want to be in the computer world. Operations only requires a very smart self-starting person. Stop watch YouTube, crack open the books and graduate ASAP. You will be challenged everyday, every minute of your life. I had to move to Houston to stay ahead. Be willing to sacrifice your and your families life. IBM is not going anywhere. They are never going out of business. How do you think the USA got to the moon and beyond? Find a US government mainframe operations job if you can running at least z/OS.

topLevelComment.author: The Rogue Nemesis
topLevelComment.text:
I'm sitting here finishing up 0.0.4 of my first Android app, an ephemeral web browser right at the 59 minute mark at the Michigan Terminal  System clip. I was struck at how simple the video was without all of today's flashy "edu-tainment" - and how limited technology accessibility was so many years ago - due to its expense, scarcity and  the  artificial "intellectual and cultural barriers."

We live in great times where someone with enough fortitude can go from zero programming knowledge to building full stack applications, on the cheap, in the comfort of their own home - and all the "free" tutorials and resources provided on the interwebs one can find.

Don't ever take such things for granted.

Happy hacking! Happy Coding! ;)

topLevelComment.author: Trae Storm
topLevelComment.text: You blow your credential in the first 45 seconds.  TCP/IP started around 1974 and  NSFNet started about 1986.  Before that, there were packet-switched networks and ARPANET/ DARPANET.  Starting by saying that "The internet started in the early 1990's" blows your entire course out the window.  If you had said the "commercial Internet" I'd give you a pass but you didn't.  As a professor at UMich, you should be more accurate.

topLevelComment.author: CJ Stoneman
topLevelComment.text: I am sorry, but you very much wrong about the Internet beginning in the 90s! I was at UCBerkeley in the early 80s and we were working on BSD Unix and the start of the Internet protocols (DNS, DHCP, TCP/IP inclusion in BCD). We were connecting Stanford, McGill Univ, Boston Univ, USC and UCB well before what you say started in the 90's. Need to do some more research, sir.

topLevelComment.author: Dave Smith
topLevelComment.text:
Hate to poo-poo this but my initial thoughts: lots missing, incorrect/incomplete or misleading. And lots of cherry picking. A couple quick examples. 

(a) Sure, you can look back and call the first packets sent "over the Internet" took place in 1969, but it certainly wasn't called the Internet then. Pre DARPANet or ARPANet would be more accurate, but that's even a stretch.  And well before, like 18 years, ARPA turned it over to NSF (NSFNet). 

(2) The Internet, as he says in his opening statement, "didn't start in the mid 1990s". That's patently false.  The commercial Internet that we have  today, where for-profit companies were allowed to send packets, began in 1990 when PSINet (then, Performance Systems International, a NYSERNet  spinoff which was a peer to MERIT), UUNet, and one other signed the CIX (Commerical Internet Exchange) in Marty Schoffstall's dinning room one night after dinner. That cleared the way for AOL and others to start to do their thing, legally.  Perhaps in making this statement about the mid 1990s he's referring to the birth of web technologies, Marc Andreessen and NCSA/Mosaic/Netscape's rise. But years before that, all the layer 1-4 companies were setting up the infrastructure necessary to power this thing.

Still don't see any reference to the critical role that commercial organizations played. I don't want to downplay the role the regional networks (like Merit, NYSERNet, CerfNet, et al) played, but they were getting funding from NSFNet and previously DARPA. 

I guess I'll have to dive deeper into this. Still looking for the first Tim Berners-Lee and Vint Cerf reference.

replies.author: Chuck Severance
